****More Money More Problems:
A Forbes Billionaires Analysis in Relation to Climate Change ****
source.ba971c4d: ** So Here's the Story ** 1. Who are the richest people in the world? > Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk are the top 2 richest people in the world 2. Which are the countries with the most billionaires? >U.S and China 3. Which are the billion dollar industries in the world (that may contribute the most to climate change)? >Finance & Investments and Tech **According to a study conducted by Our World In Data, the top industries that contribute to climate change are (in order):** > 1. Fuel > 2. Agriculture > 3. Fashion > 4. Food Retail > 5. Transport > 6. Construction work (steel, etc.) > 7. Technology The majority of the industries and sources listed effect climate change and if they are willing to accept the challenge, we can create a huge impact that could at least slow down the shifts that we've been seeing in our climate. Although, they can do more to reduce their own (hmm, jets, space visits, etc.) and their industries/companies footprint, some of the billionaires listed are actively involved in climate discussion, developing and investing in clean energy technologies - so kudos to them! **To Learn More:** **[Our World In Datat: CO2 and Greenhouse Gas Emissions](http://ourworldindata.org/co2-and-other-greenhouse-gas-emissions)** **[How Billionaires Can Help Fight Climate Change Google Search](http://https://www.google.com/search?q=How+Billionaires+Can+Help+Fight+Climate+Change&oq=How+Billionaires+Can+Help+Fight+Climate+Change&aqs=chrome..69i57.988j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8)**
source.0479d64b: **Introduction** **The Why** **This dataset contains information from the 35th Annual World's Billionaires Forbes List.** We've heard of the show, *Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?* ... But who wants to be a billionaire? Before raising your hand, pause and think about the old adage - "More Money More Problems." We've all heard of that saying right? Well, in this analysis we're not going to discuss the number of times a billionaire finds himself/herself in the middle of a divorce settlement/battle or testifying before U.S. Congress. In this analysis, we will identify the richest people in the world in order to identify those with greater social responsibility and accountability leading to global impact in areas of poverty and climate change. No, the worlds problems do not belong to billionaires - they belong to all of us - but if we can work collaboratively, we might be able to get things done. ** Data Dictionary ** * **Names** - the billionaires name * **Net Worth** - their net worth/ value of assets in billions (USD) * **Country** - the name of the country where they reside/ are citizens * **Source** - their income source * **Rank** - their global position in comparison based on their net worth * **Age** - the age of the billionaire * **Industry** - the sector, industry, or market segment of their income source (What's missing here that would have been nice to know? **Their Genders!** But I did find out the richest female billionaire is Alice Walton, the heiress of the American heiress to the fortune of Walmart. She ranks at no.17 on the list) ** Questions ** 1. Who are the richest people in the world? 2. Which are the top 10 countries with the most billionaires? 3. Which are the top 10 billion dollar industries in the world (that may contribute the most to climate change)?
